data.title: Menu bar shortcut keys and navigation issues
data.body:
There a few issues with the menu bar in Atom.

Even though `Alt + E` opens the Edit drop down menu...
- `Alt + H` - does not open the Help drop down menu
- `Alt + F` - does not open the File drop down menu

Also...
- While a drop down menu is displayed (i.e. by pressing `Alt + E` or clicking to open the menu), the Left/Right arrow keys do not move to the previous/next menus.  Up/Down arrow keys move up/down within the menu, but Left/Right do not work as expected.  Generally, Left/Right can be used to expand/collapse a submenu, but when there is no submenu to the Left/Right to expand/collapse, the keys should navigate to the previous/next menu as you would find in many other applications that utilize a conventional menu bar.

**EDIT**: Bug is present in Atom 0.194, Linux Mint 17

data.title: rendering issue with submodules
data.body:
I have a repo that contained a number of submodules.
All my submodules have been listed in the .gitignore file.

When I open a submodule with atom, it's not recognized as a git package and all its folders are greyed out. I assume it's because the parent .gitignore mentionned it.

data.title: Static analysis for XYZ language
data.body:
I'm wondering if Atom can be tweaked (via plugins) so that it can act as a real IDE for XYZ language.
And by "real IDE" I mean smart autocomplete suggestions (don't suggest method `draw()` on the object `$person`, and don't suggest the method `walk()` on the object `$shape`), static analysis, etc.

Is that possible and if so, it would be nice to have some guide explaining how one would create such a plugin for his favorite language. Maybe even create one plugin, like a reference implementation.

data.title: CPU is constantly using about 4-5% , it was around 1-2% back in 0.192
data.body:
After upgrade to 194 today , i found CPU usage increased during idle .  
I have tested using atom --safe .
I think it has to do with Cursor blinking not rendered using GPU ?
It is more evident especially using atom-block-cursor: https://github.com/olmokramer/atom-block-cursor/issues/15 , cpu usage jumps to 10-12 % 
Back in 0192 , even with atom-block-cursor pulsating (easing) animation of cursor , cpu do not consume more than 5%, averaging around 2%

data.title: Fix issue #6466 by using full path to atom
Up/down should move cursor to beginning/end in mini editor.
data.body:
This is a similar issue/request as #6445. Though as noted in the comments on the associated PR (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/6456), this issue might be trickier to get right because up/down are overloaded to do additional things in the select list (used to scroll through the options) and the `find-and-replace` UI (used to select among previous searches).

Thus, in the process of introducing new cursor behavior, the overrides in those UIs must be maintained.

data.title: Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/services/2checkoutService.ts'
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]
1. Create a file named 2Checkout.ts
2. Rename file to checkOut.ts

I'm not sure if these are the steps (or which step) resulted in the error, but this is what I was doing at the time.

When the problem occurred, the ide opened hundreds of tabs. I was not able to work again until I had manually closed all the tabs.

I have noticed a couple of related(?) issues:
1. when I rename a file in the tree, a file with the new name is created but a file with the old name remains. This only happens if the file is open in the editor (e.g. if I left-click on the tree item, then right-click and rename). If I right-click on the tree-item and rename, the file is renamed correctly.  
2. When I delete the old file from the tree, the file remains open in the editor, but with the 'trashed' name.

**System**: Mac OS X 10.10.3

data.title: Option to load entire file into memory.
data.body:
There are times (like when we use Nautilus to edit files on our server) that it would be nice to load the entire file into memory to prevent any kind of lag (such as the lag we often receive with Atom Editor when editing these files.)

Can we please get an option (or detection) that allows us to load remote files into memory for efficiency?

data.title: open previous window from command line?
data.body:
> Opening Atom without the command line (e.g. using the dock on OSX) now re-opens any previously opened windows

Would it be hard for me to do a PR to add a command-line option to open atom with the previous windows?  I know my use-case is rare but I open X11 windows from the command-line and I have no desktop at all.

I know this isn't going to happen but logically using `atom` would open previous windows and `atom .` would open the working directory.

data.title: Feature request -- Printing
data.body: I know this probably won't be at the top of the list, but I like to be able to print form my editor. It would give Atom a feature that Sublime or Brackets don' t have.

data.title: triple-click+scroll doesn't work properly
data.body:
On Atom 0.193, OSX 10.10.3
Triple-clicking (to fully select a line), then letting the left mouse button pressed and scrolling (with mouse wheel or two-finger swipe on the trackpad) doesn't work properly: it should scroll and expand the selection, but the scroll jumps back to where it was.

data.title: Command palette search results are poor
data.body:
Bring up the command palette and search "Install". Results:
- Find And Replace: Select All
- Application: Install Update
- Settings View: Uninstall Themes
- Settings View: Uninstall Packages
- Settings View: Install Packages and Themes

![untitled-1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/629141/7264772/fab661d6-e865-11e4-95b9-7f0e6993f985.png)

I'd say that we should mirror Sublime's technique, where:
- We only match the action name (or we weight the name higher)
- An exact word match (versus a partial match) should be weighted higher ("**Install** Packages" should be higher than "Un**install** Packages")
- Built in packages should be weighted higher?
- Application: Install Update should probably be intentionally weighted lower, as users will more often want to install packages I imagine

data.title: Global search different than on buffer search
data.body: If I do a search in page for `\n\s+href="\#"` it finds a couple of results. If I then do a global search for the same thing, there are no results. The options are the same: regex, case insensitive.

Result of looking at initial report from #6457

data.title: Regression: softWrapAtPreferredLineLength is ignored in 0.192
data.body:
I normally want to see files soft-wrapped to the width of the window. In 0.188, I was able to set `softWrap: true` and it would do this. In 0.192, however, it soft-wraps to preferred line length, even if I explicitly set `softWrapAtPreferredLineLength: false`. I think this is a regression...or should I be doing something different?

(I'm using Mac OS X 10.10, if that makes any difference.)

data.title: Add david-dm dependency status badge to Readme
data.body:
This adds a dependency status badge (from https://david-dm.org) to the Readme to make it a bit easier to keep track of dependency up-to-date-ness. Unfortunately, this only works for dependencies in `atom/atom/package.json` and not `atom/atom/build/package.json` (they don't support subdirectories... yet). This should make it a bit easier to keep track of dependency versions and see when we're out of date.

Eventually I'd like to add this to all package Readmes too, but that will come with @atom/issue-triage's big rewrites.

data.title: core:select-up/down should work in mini editor as well as main editor.
data.body: Fixes #6445.

data.title: No Content Left Behind
data.body:
From https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/6380#issuecomment-94878888

> I think it's critical. It's not about atom crashing or not crashing. It's about a myriad of other things crashing on a computer. It's about being able to not kill a junior because he or she accidentally hit the reset button on your computer. Sublime gives you the "don't worry about it" guarantee. It's a state of mind and affects your workflow. I was used to having many unnamed buffers open with random scratch data. I didn't need to save it anywhere but sublime kept them around.

---

From @maxbrunsfeld on https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/6380#issuecomment-94881588

> I think this use case is covered though, because Atom should quit normally during a system restart (at least on OSX and Linux).

Not when I hard reset my computer with a physical reset button which is quite accessible and happens to be right next to the USB ports.

---

Open atom, type some text, and hit `Ctrl+Q`

![screenshot from 2015-04-21 10 40 49](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/753919/7258673/e6d837c8-e812-11e4-8232-c4f8d736fb5c.png)

I should not be able to lose work at all, at any time, for any reason. In sublime I can do the above and then immediately re-open and all is well.

---

To summarize, we need a few things:
- Save unnamed buffers when atom is closed normally
- Porting the "hot exit" feature from sublime. When atom is closed, it is immediately closed without any popup and can be re-opened in the exact state it was left
- On some configurable interval we save the state to allow the application to pick back up in case of fire

data.title: Distinguish whether a Marker is visible on screen (versus fully folded)
data.body: Here's a scenario to illustrate the problem: Let's say we create a Decoration on a certain Marker. This Marker spans buffer rows 2-3. Row 0 is then folded, and let's say this collapses buffer rows 0-5. What We Expect The Decoration should not be visible at all, because buffer rows 2-3 are entirely contained within the collapsed range. Actual Behavior The `decoration.getMarker().getScreenRange()` returns row 0 (i.e. the row that rows 2-3 were collapsed into), which indicates that the Decoration should be visible on screen at row 0. Possible Solutions In discussion with @nathansobo, it seems like changing `Marker::getScreenRange` to return null in this situation is not a viable option now, because that's likely to break many packages. One solution could be to add a `visibleOnScreen` property to `Marker`.

data.title: Uploading to local file system
data.body:
At my webfirm, we host sites on our servers. We have access to it via out Network tab. However no one has ever needed to FTP to the server.

Is there a way to use Atom to connect to a File System? The Target Location is something like this

```
\\Server\www\domain.dev.com
```

While I can just work off the server, we use bitbucket to keep a history of changes in the repo, so working off the server isn't really an option. 

Any suggestions? I am using SFTP for our wordpress sites which we use Media Temple for, so I have no issues there. I'm just not a fan of Visual Studio to work on our hosted sites.

data.title: Atom will not launch from a USB flash drive when setting `ATOM_HOME`
data.body:
Most of the details can be found at this post:
https://discuss.atom.io/t/starting-atom-via-command-line-does-not-launch-it-correctly/16279/2

I recently tried to run atom portable. I would like to keep all my themes and packages on the drive as well, so I created a .atom folder on my flash drive using `md .atom`. After that, I extracted the latest zip distribution of Atom into an `Atom` folder on my flash drive. To set `ATOM_HOME` and launch atom, I used the following script:

```
@echo off
set ATOM_HOME= "E:/.atom"
start E:/Atom/atom.exe --safe
echo ATOM_HOME currently at %ATOM_HOME%
echo.
pause
```

When trying to run this script, I got

```
[4924:0421/080402:INFO:CONSOLE(67)] "RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
```

The rest of the stack trace can be found at the above link. Oddly, after I `REM`ed out the `set ATOM_HOME= "E:/.atom"`, atom launched fine from the flash drive. Is there anyway this can be fixed?

data.body:
Press enter after the last character of the comment below, it should not indent.

``` typescript

 [but I got one space before me]
```

data.title: Make Travis build more resilient
Perform DOM updates requested from DOM reads in the same frame, after we finish reading
data.body:
A common pattern is to put something on the DOM, measure it, then update the DOM again based on that measurement. This change ensures that any updates requested as a result of reading from the DOM get scheduled for the end of the current frame. If you want to read _again_ after these follow-on updates, you will need to wait for the next frame. But at least this way we ensure instant feedback with minimal thrashing (1 reflow) when we have no choice but to read the DOM before updating.

/cc @benogle

data.title: Command Palette disapears when plugin loads (external) bootstrap
Do not bundle package specs
data.body:
#6395 removed core specs and fixtures and this PR removes package specs and fixtures from the bundle to reduce the size.

It also removes a bunch of other unneeded files from the app bundle that I noticed while auditing.

This removes around **~2,500** unneeded files from the app which shrinks `app.asar` by 3MB.

data.title: :arrow_up: babel-core@5.1.11
data.body:
Bump babel-core from 4.0.2 to 5.1.11.

Note that this is a major version bump, so `babel.coffee` also had to be updated to reflect the minor API changes.

Notable new features from the [changelog](https://github.com/babel/babel/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md) since 4.0.2:
- Add [trailing function comma proposal](https://github.com/jeffmo/es-trailing-function-commas).
- Decorators based on [@wycat's stage 1 proposal](https://github.com/wycats).

There is a number of bug fixes and performance improvements, as well.

One new error that users are likely to run into is this one in subclass constructors that reference `this` but not `super`:

```
'this' is not allowed before super()
```

As best I can tell, this was a recent-ish update to the ES6 constructor semantics spec that Babel is now enforcing: https://gist.github.com/allenwb/53927e46b31564168a1d. /cc @sebmck
